questions.question: A therapist discusses the sexual response cycle with a patient. Which of the following statements is false about the sexual response cycle?

options.A: The excitement stage involves increased blood pressure and heart rate.
options.B: Males experience swelling of the glans and testes during the plateau stage.
options.C: Females experience contractions of the vagina during orgasm.
options.D: Both genders have a refractory period after orgasm.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Both genders have a refractory period after orgasm. Explanation: Males experience a refractory period after ejaculation, during which they cannot become aroused again for a period of time. Females do not have a refractory period and can often become aroused again quickly after orgasm. Phases of the sexual response cycle Desire phase Consists of sex fantasies and the desire to have sex Associated disorder: Hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) FDA drug approved to treat HSDD in premenopausal women Flibanserin- Partial 5HT1A agonist, oral drug Bremelanotide- Melanocortin receptor agonist, subcutaneous injection) Excitement Stage Muscles tense, heart rate and blood pressure increase. (Option A ruled out) Males: Penis becomes erect. Females: Vaginal walls become moist and wider; clitoris enlarges. Associated disorder: Male erectile dysfunction, Female Sexual arousal disorder Plateau Stage Breathing becomes faster; muscles continue to tense. Males: Glans swell; testes enlarge. (Option B ruled out) Females: Outer vagina contracts; clitoris retracts. Orgasm Stage Neuromuscular tension releases. Males: Penis contracts, ejaculating sperm and semen. Females: Vagina contracts rhythmically. (Option C ruled out) Associated disorder: Female orgasmic disorder, premature ejaculation, delayed ejaculation. Resolution Stage The body gradually returns to its resting state. Males: Penis shrinks; includes a refractory period where further arousal is not possible. Females: No refractory period; can become aroused again quickly. Reference: Sexual response cycle

questions.question: A 50-year-old man reports to his doctor that he is having difficulty achieving an erection during intercourse. He mentions this issue has been ongoing for the past year, despite having previously enjoyed a healthy sex life. Which statement about his condition is TRUE?

options.A: Erectile dysfunction is common in all ageing men.
options.B: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors can be safely used with nitrates.
options.C: Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations.
options.D: Organic Erectile Dysfunction occurs in men with relationship issues.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Situational erectile disorder means he can achieve erections in certain situations. Incidence increases with age; reported in 2-8% of young adults and is more common in older men. Not universal in aging; factors like having a partner and consistent sexual activity are protective. (Option A) Episodes of erectile disorder can increase anxiety in future sexual encounters. Causes: Organic Causes: Due to medical conditions or medications. Medical Conditions: Cardiovascular diseases (hypertension, atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease), Diabetes mellitus, Neurological disorders (multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, spinal cord injuries), Endocrine disorders (hypogonadism, hyperprolactinemia, thyroid dysfunction), Chronic kidney disease, Liver cirrhosis, Pelvic or prostate surgeries, Sleep disorders (obstructive sleep apnea). Medications: Antihypertensives (beta-blockers, thiazide diuretics), Antidepressants (SSRIs, tricyclic antidepressants), Antipsychotics (typical and atypical), Anti-androgens (finasteride, spironolactone), Opioids, Chemotherapy agents, Anticonvulsants, H2-receptor antagonists (cimetidine). Psychogenic Causes: More common in young and middle-aged men; often related to psychological factors such as fear, anxiety, or relationship issues. (Option D) Types of Male Erectile Disorder: Lifelong Male Erectile Disorder: Never able to achieve an erection sufficient for insertion. (Option B) Rare, occurring in about 1% of men under 35. Acquired Male Erectile Disorder: Previously able to achieve penetration but later unable to do so. Affects 10-20% of all men. Situational Male Erectile Disorder: Able to have erections in certain situations (e.g., with a sex worker) but not with a partner. Investigations used to record nocturnal erections are: Nocturnal penile tumescence Penile plethysmography (which measures blood pressure in the penis). These are used to differentiate between organic and psychogenic erectile dysfunction. Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction Pharmacotherapy Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDE-5 inhibitors) Nitric oxide enhancers- facilitates blood flow into the penis and enhances erection. Drugs- Sildenafil, tadalafil, vardenafil and Avanafil. Not used along with organic nitrates- Can cause sudden fall in blood pressure and can be fatal. (Option B) Other medications: Oral phentolamine : May reduce sympathetic tone and relax muscles of corpora cavernosa and subsequently improve the erection. Alprostadil contains naturally occurring prostaglandin E (vasodilating agent). Alprostadil- Directly injected into corpora cavernosa or given intraurethral through a cannula as a pellet.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man visits his doctor expressing frustration with his sexual performance. He reports that he ejaculates within 30 seconds of vaginal penetration, which has caused distress in his relationship. Which of the following treatments is not typically used for premature ejaculation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sildenafil Explanation: Sildenafil is used to treat erectile dysfunction, not premature ejaculation. It works by increasing blood flow to the penis but does not address the timing of ejaculation. Premature Ejaculation (PME) A pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after vaginal penetration. DSM-5- Ejaculation occurs within <1 minute following vaginal penetration The cause of PME is usually psychogenic. Ejaculation (PME) treatment" data-author="" data-hash="1174" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="March2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/FEpnBa0ExDBZVS8Yf0SO1742541734.png" /> Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Pages 1663, 1664, 1686, 1688-1692

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with concerns about her inability to achieve orgasm during sexual activity with her partner. She reports that this has been an ongoing issue for the past 8 months and is causing distress in her relationship. She has normal sexual desire but is unable to reach orgasm despite adequate stimulation She has no history of medical conditions or medication use that might explain these symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the DSM-5 criteria?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Female orgasmic disorder Explanation: The patient's symptoms of persistent inability to achieve orgasm during sexual activity, lasting for at least 6 months and causing distress, align with the diagnostic criteria for female orgasmic disorder, according to DSM-5. Female orgasmic disorder (DSM-5) Definition Recurrent or persistent inhibition of female orgasm, as manifested by delay in, or absence of orgasm after a normal sexual excitement phase Duration ≥ 6 months Symptoms Difficulties with orgasms Delayed/reduced frequency of orgasms Reduced intensity of orgasms Diagnostic Criteria ≥ 1 symptom during most sexual encounters Treatment Psychotherapy Hypoactive sexual desire disorder (Option A): Hypoactive sexual desire disorder involves a reduced sexual desire, which is not mentioned in the patient's presentation. Female sexual interest/arousal disorder (Option B): Female sexual interest/arousal disorder involves a lack of sexual interest or arousal, which is not the primary complaint here. Sexual aversion disorder (Option D): Sexual aversion disorder is not a DSM-5 diagnosis and involves an aversion to sexual contact, which is not described in this case. Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 1657, 1658, 1659

questions.question: A 7-year-old child assigned female at birth has been consistently expressing a strong desire to be a boy for the past 2.5 years. The child prefers traditionally masculine clothing, toys, and activities, and becomes upset when referred to as a girl. What is the most appropriate diagnosis according to the ICD-11 criteria?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Gender incongruence in childhood Explanation: This case meets the criteria for gender incongruence of childhood as defined by ICD-11: There is a marked incongruence between the child's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex. The child shows a strong desire to be a different gender than the assigned sex. The child exhibits preferences for clothes, toys, and activities typical of the experienced gender. The duration of symptoms (2.5 years) exceeds the requirement of 2 years. The child shows distress when gender identity is not acknowledged (upset when referred to as a girl). The child is prepubertal. According to ICD-11 , gender dysphoria has been classified into: Gender incongruence of adolescence or adulthood (Option C) : A marked incongruence between an individual's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex, lasting at least 6 months, manifesting in adolescence or adulthood. Gender incongruence of childhood: A marked incongruence between a child's experienced/expressed gender and assigned sex, lasting at least 6 months, manifesting before puberty onset. Gender incongruence, unspecified: A condition where an individual experiences a mismatch between their gender identity and assigned sex, without specifying age of onset or meeting full diagnostic criteria. Previously in ICD-10 , gender dysphoria consisted of: Transsexualism (Option A): Desire to live as the opposite sex, often seeking surgery and hormone therapy. Dual-role transvestism (Option B): Cross-dressing without a desire for permanent sex change. Gender identity disorder of childhood : Persistent discomfort with one's gender starting in childhood. Reference: ICD-11 WHO

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents to the psychiatric clinic with distressing thoughts and behaviors involving intense sexual arousal from observing unsuspecting individuals in private settings. He reports that he has experienced these urges for several years and has acted on them multiple times, which has caused legal and interpersonal problems. Which of the following paraphilias best fits his symptoms?
questions.explanation: of unaware individuals who are nude or involved in sexual activities. Disorders of Sexual Preference (Paraphilias/Perversions): Fetishism (Option C) In fetishism, sexual interest centers on objects (such as shoes, gloves, or stockings) closely linked to the human body, or on non-genital body parts. The latter focus is sometimes called partialism. Exclusively found in men. Exhibitionism (Option B) Exhibitionism is the recurrent urge to expose the genitals to a stranger or an unsuspecting person. Almost exclusively found in men. Transvestism/ Eonism Previously known as transvestic fetishism. Trans means opposite and vest means clothes Persons dressing in opposite gender clothes for sexual pleasure. Frotteurism Characterized by a man rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman to achieve orgasm. Voyeurism Persistent focus on fantasies and behaviors involving the observation of unaware individuals who are nude or involved in sexual activities Also known as scopophilia Masochism (Option D) Recurrent sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer. Sadism Recurrent sexual arousal from the physical or psychological suffering of another person. Pedophilia Pedophilia involves recurrent intense sexual urges toward, or arousal by, children. As per DSM-5, the child must be under 14 years old, and the patient must be at least 16 years old and at least five years older than the victims. Other paraphilic disorders Necrophilia: Obtaining sexual gratification from corpses/cadavers. Zoophilia: Sexual arousal from animals. Telephone and computer scatologia: Sexual arousal involving obscene phone calls or obscene messages/images to unsuspecting persons. Coprophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to defecate on a partner/to be defecated on/eat feces. Urophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to urinate on a partner/to be urinated on. Klismaphilia: Use of enemas for sexual stimulation. Treatment: Psychotherapy - Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT) Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 1695-1710

questions.question: Which of the following paraphilias involves sexual arousal from interaction with corpses?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Necrophilia Explanation: Necrophilia is a type of paraphilic disorder that refers to obtaining sexual gratification from corpses/cadavers. Necrophilia (Option A): Obtaining sexual gratification from corpses/cadavers. Zoophilia: Sexual arousal from animals. Telephone and computer scatologia: Sexual arousal involving obscene phone calls or obscene messages/images to unsuspecting persons. Coprophilia (Option B): Sexual pleasure associated with desire to defecate on a partner/to be defecated on/eat feces. Urophilia: Sexual pleasure associated with desire to urinate on a partner/to be urinated on. Klismaphilia (Option C): Use of enemas for sexual stimulation. Nymphomania (Option D) is a type of sexual addiction which includes abnormal, excessive, insatiable desire in a woman for sexual intercourse. In a man, a similar condition is called satyriasis , which involves excessive sexual desire in males. Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 1695-1710

questions.question: Which of the following sexual pain disorders involves painful intercourse due to involuntary muscle spasms in the pelvic floor?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Vaginismus Explanation: Vaginismus is a constriction of the outer third of the vagina due to involuntary pelvic floor muscle tightening or spasm. It interferes with penile insertion and intercourse. Genito-Pelvic Pain/Penetration Disorder: In DSM-5, this disorder refers to one or more of the following complaints, of which any two or more may occur together: Difficulty having intercourse Genito-pelvic pain Fear of pain or penetration Tension of the pelvic floor muscles These pain disorders are diagnosed as dyspareunia or vaginismus: Dyspareunia (Option B): Recurrent or persistent genital pain occurring before, during, or after intercourse. Although they frequently coexist, it does not specifically involve involuntary muscle spasms making vaginismus a better answer here. Vaginismus: IIIIIII It is the constriction of the outer third of the vagina due to involuntary pelvic floor muscle tightening or spasm. It interferes with penile insertion and intercourse. Treatment: Dilating vagina (or) opening with fingers or with dilators. Dilators may also help in dyspareunia. Sexual aversion disorder (Option A) is characterized by a strong aversion to sexual activity, rather than physical pain during penetration. Vulvodynia (Option D) refers to chronic vulvar pain that is not associated with an identifiable cause, which can occur during sexual activity, but it is not primarily caused by muscle spasms. Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 1666-1670
